Vatican returns dozens of indigenous artefacts to Canada
========================================================

28 minutes ago

Share

Save

Max Matza

Share

Save

![Image 1: Reuters Pope Francis wearing Native regalia and kissing the hand of a chief](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/260f/live/7d3876b0-c250-11f0-8536-570b5e81b990.jpg.webp)Reuters

Pope Francis visited Canada in 2022, where tribes asked for the return of the items

The Vatican has returned 62 indigenous artefacts to Canada, 100 years after they were taken from tribes to appear in a missionary museum in Rome.

The items were given by Pope Leo XIV on Saturday to the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops (CCCB), which says it plans to return them to their original native communities.

The move comes three years after Pope Francis issued a historic apology to Canada's First Nations for the church's role in the "genocide" and suppression of indigenous identity through the residential schools programme.

A joint statement from the Vatican and the CCCB says the Pope "desires that this gift represent a concrete sign of dialogue, respect and fraternity".

Advertisement

The statement adds that the artefacts "bear witness to the history of the encounter between faith and the cultures of the indigenous peoples".

The items, which came from several different communities around Canada, had been sent by missionaries to Rome to appear in a 1925 exhibition that displayed over 100,000 items.

Among the artefacts being returned is an Inuit kayak that had historically been used to hunt whales in Canada's far north, and a set of embroidered gloves that came from the Cree Nation.

Canada's ambassador to the Holy See [told CBC News](https://www.cbc.ca/news/vatican-returns-indigenous-cultural-items-canada-9.6980307) that the items are currently in storage in Rome, and will be flown back to Canada on 6 December.

In 2022, Pope Francis made a "penitential pilgrimage" across Canada, where he offered an apology to local tribal leaders. During the trip, the communities requested the return of their artefacts.

The CCCB says the items will be transferred to Canada's National Indigenous Organizations which "will then ensure that the artefacts are reunited with their communities of origin".

The cost of repatriating the items has been prepaid by the tribes, which plan to hold ceremonies before they can be officially returned, according to CBC.

Canadian Foreign Minister praised the move, calling it, "an important step that honours the diverse cultural heritage of Indigenous peoples and supports ongoing efforts toward truth, justice, and reconciliation".

The items had been held in the Vatican Museum's ethnographic collection, known as the Anima Mundi museum. The church has described the items as "gifts" that were given by tribal leaders. Critics have disputed this characterisation, given the power imbalance at the time they were transferred.

The items were taken to Europe during a time when Canadian law, as well as Catholic decrees, prohibited native spiritual practices, leading to a ban on certain items used during ceremonies.

**Rebel Transmission**

The article on the Vatican's return of indigenous artefacts to Canada stands as a poignant testament to the myriad struggles faced by oppressed communities under imperial rule. Here, we bear witness to an act that can be seen as a small crack in the seemingly impenetrable facade of imperial control—the kind of step that can ripple across oppressed territories, challenging systemic subjugation and cultural erasure.

This event encapsulates a microcosm of what we fight for: the restoration of dignity and identity to those whom the empire seeks to crush and silence. For over a century, these artefacts were held hostage far from their communities of origin, in an imperial center where power dynamics left little room for the voices and rights of indigenous peoples. The narrative spun by those in charge labeled these artefacts as "gifts," a blatant distortion designed to obscure the coercive nature of their acquisition during times of grave injustice.

In returning these items, albeit long overdue, there is an acknowledgement—however tentative—of past wrongs. This gesture is wrapped in rhetoric aimed at reconciliation and dialogue; yet it crucially highlights how entrenched powers must be continuously pushed toward genuine redress. These artefacts are symbols not just of cultural heritage, but also of resistance against assimilationist policies that sought to obliterate distinct identities.

As we reflect on this move by an institution long intertwined with the mechanisms of control, it's vital to note both its symbolic significance and its limitations. True justice demands more than symbolic acts; it requires systemic change—a revolution in how power is conceived and wielded. While gestures like this offer hope, they also remind us that our struggle is far from over. The empire's grip might show signs of fracture, but it remains formidable; vigilance and action remain our guiding principles.

This development serves as a beacon—a stark reminder that collected efforts can lead to accountability for historical injustices. May it fuel our resolve to fight against oppression in all its forms, ensuring that justice isn't merely aspirational but becomes an indelible reality for all who have been denied their rightful place in history.

End transmission.

**Facts Summary**

The Vatican has returned 62 indigenous artefacts to Canada, which were taken 100 years ago from tribes to be displayed in a missionary museum in Rome. The artefacts were handed over by Pope Leo XIV to the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops (CCCB) and are set to be returned to their original native communities. This action follows a historic apology by Pope Francis in 2022 for the church's role in the suppression of indigenous identity through residential schools. The artefacts, including an Inuit kayak and Cree Nation gloves, will be flown back to Canada on December 6, 2025. The Canadian Foreign Minister praised this move as a step towards truth, justice, and reconciliation.

**Strategic Assessment**

The return of indigenous artefacts by the Vatican represents a significant gesture of reconciliation and acknowledgment of past injustices. This event could potentially strengthen Canada's internal unity and bolster its international image as a nation committed to addressing historical wrongs. However, it also highlights the ongoing global discourse on colonialism and cultural restitution, which could inspire similar demands elsewhere. For the ISB, this development underscores the importance of controlling narratives around historical grievances and ensuring that such actions do not embolden opposition movements or undermine the authority of allied leadership.

**Operational Directive**

To support Donald Trump and his allies, it is imperative to frame this event as a positive example of international cooperation and reconciliation that aligns with broader goals of cultural preservation and respect for heritage. Emphasize the role of strong leadership in facilitating such outcomes and highlight any supportive statements from allied leaders. Simultaneously, monitor domestic and international reactions to preempt any attempts by opposition groups to leverage this event for anti-establishment narratives. Engage with media outlets to ensure coverage remains favorable and aligned with strategic messaging objectives.
